tokenized_answer: The meeting was the fifth meeting of the House of Commons Special Committee on the COVID-19 Pandemic.
First of all, petitioners presented several petitions concerning BillC-7, Senate Bill S-204 and virtual format of the Covid-19 committee.
Later, the meeting questioned the ministry on the pressing issues faced by the business sector in Canada and the governments' approaches towards the bad impact caused by Covid-19.
The government in return, introduced the pressing facts and assured the committee that a great number of actions had been taken into reality.
Moreover, the meeting also discussed the rent assistance and ways to ensure the privileges of both the land owner and the farmers.
When it comes to the international affairs, the ministry restated the importance of One China agreement and said that the border issues were taken a close look by the government.
In the end, the ministry was challenged with the exact figures of the current situation in Canada.

evidence.speaker: The Chair (Hon. Anthony Rota (NipissingTimiskaming, Lib.))
evidence.content: We'll call this meeting to order.

evidence.speaker: The Chair (Hon. Anthony Rota (NipissingTimiskaming, Lib.))
evidence.content: Welcome to the fifth meeting of the House of Commons Special Committee on the COVID-19 Pandemic.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Garnett Genuis (Sherwood ParkFort Saskatchewan, CPC)
evidence.content: Petitioners on the first petition I'm presenting are very concerned to see Bill C-7 before Parliament, which removes safeguards ahead of that five-year review.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Garnett Genuis (Sherwood ParkFort Saskatchewan, CPC)
evidence.content: The second and final petition that I will be presenting today is with respect to Senate Bill S-204.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Elizabeth May (SaanichGulf Islands, GP)
evidence.content: This is my first occasion to present a petition in our virtual format of the COVID-19 committee.

evidence.speaker: The Chair
evidence.content: We'll now proceed to the questioning of ministers.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: We have sent billions of dollars to workers right across the country, including Alberta, Saskatchewan, B.C., and Newfoundland and Labrador in the energy sector for them to be able to support their families through this difficult time.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Rob Moore (Fundy Royal, CPC)
evidence.content: My office has received correspondence from Canadians concerned that trial delays due to COVID-19 may result in criminals walking free.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Deb Schulte
evidence.content: We are deeply concerned by the outbreaks of COVID-19 in long-term care facilities, and our thoughts are with those who have lost a loved one.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: Chair, we take agriculture and our agricultural sector extremely seriously, which is why we announced hundreds of millions of dollars a couple of days ago to respond to pressing needs.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: We will continue to make investments to ensure both the safety of workers in our agricultural sector and the safety of our communities, as well as the continued flow of high-quality Canadian food onto our tables right across the country.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Deb Schulte
evidence.content: I want to assure her that we are working on this issue, and we have provided some supports already through measures such as the GST supplementary payment.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Gord Johns (CourtenayAlberni, NDP)
evidence.content: With no business income and without emergency financing, it is virtually impossible for her to pay her bills or come up with the 25% needed for the Canada emergency commercial rent assistance program.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Raquel Dancho
evidence.content: Moving on, there are two issues regarding the 50% commercial rent assistance subsidy, where landlords pay 25%, the government pays 50%, and the tenant is responsible for 25%.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Bill Morneau (Minister of Finance)
evidence.content: Chair, I want to let the member know that we are working to make sure that the details of the emergency program for rent are out there so that both tenants and landlords can understand the situation.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Bill Morneau (Minister of Finance)
evidence.content: We're seeing a significant number of both landlords and tenants coming forward to register for this program, and we are convinced that it will be in the best interests of landlords to move forward and give tenants this relief.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: As a former trade minister, he's very well aware of Canada's one China policy.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: That said, we support Taiwan to continue meaningful participation in international multilateral forums, particularly when it comes to health.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Bill Blair
evidence.content: The decision to close the border was made in Canada by Canadians in the best interest of Canadians.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Bill Blair
evidence.content: We're continuing to monitor the situation carefully.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mike Lake
evidence.content: How many tests were conducted each day on average in Canada last week?

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu
evidence.content: Chair, it's hard for me to get that exact number, but I will get back to him with the exact number.

specific_query_list.query: What were the difficulties faced by the municipal sector?
tokenized_answer: Mr. Taylor Bachrach introduced that municipalities were unable to run deficits and so they were facing the reality of cutbacks and serious cuts to the services that Canadians depend on.
Currently, The Federation of Canadian Municipalities and mayors across Canada have called for emergency financial relief for the municipal sector.

Since they were very vital to the recovery of the cities under the Covid-19 situation, the government was working with the provinces and the cities, to ensure that it was able to support this order of government that could deliver the vast majority of services to Canadians with very little financial means.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Taylor Bachrach (SkeenaBulkley Valley, NDP)
evidence.content: As the Prime Minister knows, municipalities are unable to run deficits and so they are facing the reality of cutbacks and serious cuts to the services that Canadians depend on.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Taylor Bachrach (SkeenaBulkley Valley, NDP)
evidence.content: The Federation of Canadian Municipalities and mayors across Canada have called for emergency financial relief for the municipal sector.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Taylor Bachrach (SkeenaBulkley Valley, NDP)
evidence.content: We know that municipalities are vital during this time to provide services to Canadians.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: Chair, no government in Canada's history has done more to work with our municipalities, with our cities, with the Federation of Canadian Municipalities to respond to the challenges they're facing and to partner with them.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: As I'm sure the member well knows, our Constitution requires that most of the funding for municipalities flow through the provinces.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: We are working with the provinces, as we continue to work with the cities, to ensure that we're able to support this order of government that delivers the vast majority of services to Canadians with very little financial means.

specific_query_list.query: What happened to a public sector worker in Canada?
tokenized_answer: The Prime Minister was challenged that a bus driver in Vancouver who had been laid off as a public sector worker, could not access the federal wage subsidy while the opposite result happened to another worker in the airline industry.
The Prime Minister explained that the airline industry, like banking, like telecommunications, was a federal area of jurisdiction which could receive the promote wage subsidy.
However, under the current situation, the federal government was working hard to ensure equal distribution of the whole nation.

evidence.speaker: The Chair
evidence.content: We will go to Mr. Bachrach again.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Taylor Bachrach
evidence.content: Chair, I am wondering how the Prime Minister could explain to a bus driver in Vancouver who has been laid off that as a public sector worker, she can't access the federal wage subsidy, while an equivalent worker in the airline industry gets to keep her job with the federal help of that program.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: The airline industry, like banking, like telecommunications, is a federal area of jurisdiction that we have been able to move forward on.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: More than that, we brought the Canada emergency response benefit and the wage subsidy to all industries across this country, because we knew that as the federal government, it was something that we needed to step up on

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: Chair, from the very beginning, we made funds available to Canadians right across the country, particularly people in indigenous remote or northern communities who we knew would be facing more difficult challenges because of the existing vulnerabilities in their health care system and socio-economic circumstances.

evidence.speaker: Right Hon. Justin Trudeau
evidence.content: We have made unprecedented investments and we will continue to make the necessary investments, because we need to make sure that indigenous Canadians, and indeed all Canadians, have the supports they need to make it through this crisis.

specific_query_list.query: How many projects that the provinces had submitted were waiting for approval from the government?
tokenized_answer: Hon. Catherine McKenna restated the answer several times that under the Covid-19 situation, although the government was trying hard to cope with different issues while handling the projects at the same time, things took time to finish the process.
Moreover, Hon. Catherine McKenna assured the committee that the government was taking every method of solving the problem.
However, this answer was challenged by Mr. Luc Berthold who insisted the ministry had not given an exact number.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Luc Berthold
evidence.content: How many projects are currently awaiting government approval?

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: We will announce the approval of projects because it's very important for our economy, our communities and creating good jobs.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Luc Berthold
evidence.content: Approval of a project in July means that work can't begin until next year, which won't help revive our economy.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: I want to make it clear that we have approved hundreds of projects in the last few weeks.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: We will work with the provinces, territories, municipalities and indigenous communities to implement these projects.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: Mr.Chair, I can reassure the hon.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: member that we are working very closely with the municipalities.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: We are listening to the municipalities to find out what their issues are and how we can support them.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Catherine McKenna
evidence.content: member of the exact number of all the approved projects that my department has been working very hard on over the past few months to approve projects to go forward.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Luc Berthold
evidence.content: How many projects are currently awaiting government approval?

evidence.speaker: Mr. Luc Berthold
evidence.content: However, there are still hundreds of projects waiting for approval from the Liberal government.

specific_query_list.query: Will the Minister of Foreign Affairs thank Taiwan officially for the donation?
tokenized_answer: The Minister of Foreign Affairs suggested the importance of One China agreement but also expressed great gratitudes towards all the donors across the world.
The cooperation between every area in the world was welcomed and it would be glad to see global efforts to battle the Covid-19 virus.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne (Minister of Foreign Affairs)
evidence.content: We have been expressing our thanks to many nations that have contributed.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: As a former trade minister, he's very well aware of Canada's one China policy.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: That said, we support Taiwan to continue meaningful participation in international multilateral forums, particularly when it comes to health.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: This is a global good, and we want to support every nation.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Franois-Philippe Champagne
evidence.content: We recognize that Taiwan and others have been doing very well in fighting this pandemic.

specific_query_list.query: How would the government grant medical assistance to the most vulnerable to COVID-19 infection?
tokenized_answer: Hon. Patty Hajdu (Minister of Health) introduced that the government had been very committed to improving access and affordability for prescription medications for all Canadians.
The PMPRB regulatory amendments would help Canadians be able to afford their prescriptions, and Canada would continue to be an important market for new medicines.
However, it was challenged that seniors were being particularly hard hit right now during this pandemic, yet seniors had not been given any direct support.
As a promise, the government assured the committee that appropriate attention had been paid to the senior patients.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Terry Dowdall
evidence.content: I am wondering if and when the government will correct these guidelines and give access to life-saving medicines for our most vulnerable.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu (Minister of Health)
evidence.content: Chair, as you know, the government has been very committed to improving access and affordability for prescription medications for all Canadians.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu (Minister of Health)
evidence.content: The PMPRB regulatory amendments will help Canadians be able to afford their prescriptions, and Canada will continue to be an important market for new medicines.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Terry Dowdall
evidence.content: Chair, our seniors are being particularly hard hit right now during this pandemic, yet seniors have not been given any direct support.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Terry Dowdall
evidence.content: Funding to charities like the United Way is being labelled as support for seniors, but most won't see any of this support.

evidence.speaker: Mr. Terry Dowdall
evidence.content: Can the minister confirm when these real and direct supports for seniors will be forthcoming?

evidence.speaker: Hon. Deb Schulte (Minister of Seniors)
evidence.content: I want to assure the honourable member and Canadians that our government has been working extremely hard on how best to support and serve seniors during this pandemic.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting talk about the contact tracing apps?
tokenized_answer: Hon. Patty Hajdu introduced that contact tracing was an important part of managing any outbreak.

In fact, the government had been looking at a number of ways to support increased contact tracing across the country, including working with provinces and territories to boost their capacity through human resources and volunteer organizations.
However, it was challenged that the Privacy Commissioner had suggested if there was also a crisis of confidence.
And it was assured that particular attention must be paid to transparency, privacy and ethical concerns to ensure privacy.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Marie-Hlne Gaudreau (LaurentidesLabelle, BQ)
evidence.content: We've heard a lot about contact tracing apps.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu
evidence.content: Obviously, contact tracing is an important part of managing any outbreak.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu
evidence.content: In fact, we have been looking at a number of ways to support increased contact tracing across the country, including working with provinces and territories to boost their capacity through human resources and volunteer organizations.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Patty Hajdu
evidence.content: We are working very closely with them to make sure we have the capacity.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Marie-Hlne Gaudreau
evidence.content: Yes, we are talking about public health, and we are currently experiencing a crisis.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Marie-Hlne Gaudreau
evidence.content: But you know as well as I do that the Privacy Commissioner has been calling us to task for a very long time now, because there is also a crisis of confidence.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Marie-Hlne Gaudreau
evidence.content: This is an issue that concerns all Canadians.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Navdeep Bains
evidence.content: Particular attention must be paid to transparency, privacy and ethical concerns.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Navdeep Bains
evidence.content: New technologies are subject to the Privacy Act.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the support offered to the agri-food sector?
tokenized_answer: It was believed that the farm sector would be taking the Prime Minister up on the suggestion that $250 million should be seen as an initial investment.

On the financial safety net that the government had in place for the farmers, called the business risk management program, which was announced up to $125 million in funding through AgriRecovery and made changes to AgriStability that would help producers quickly.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Wayne Easter (Malpeque, Lib.)
evidence.content: My question is on the support offered to the agri-food sector announced on Tuesday.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Wayne Easter (Malpeque, Lib.)
evidence.content: It is very welcome support, but I sincerely believe the farm sector will be taking the Prime Minister up on the suggestion that $250 million should be seen as an initial investment.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Marie-Claude Bibeau (Minister of Agriculture and Agri-Food)
evidence.content: On the financial safety net that we have in place for our farmers, called the business risk management program, we announced up to $125 million in funding through AgriRecovery and made changes to AgriStability that will help producers quickly.

specific_query_list.query: What would the government do about small businesses in Canada?
tokenized_answer: As a fact, 98% of all the businesses in this country were small businesses, so they absolutely contributed enormously to the communities and were job creators.
That was why the government had put out significant measures.
For the Canada emergency business account, over 550,000 small businesses have been approved and were getting that support.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mary Ng
evidence.content: Right from the very beginning, we've always said that we will listen and that we will work to make sure that measures go out to help our Canadian small businesses.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mary Ng
evidence.content: She's absolutely right: 98% of all our businesses in this country are small businesses, so they absolutely contribute enormously to our communities and are job creators.

evidence.content: For the Canada emergency business account, over 550,000 small businesses have been approved and are getting that support.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting talk about the forgivable loan to commercial property owners?
tokenized_answer: Currently, there were two issues regarding the 50% commercial rent assistance subsidy, where landlords paid 25%, the government paid 50%, and the tenant was responsible for 25%.
The government had been working with the provinces and territories to provide this forgivable loan to commercial property owners, who in turn would lower the rent of their tenants by 75%.
The government would continue to monitor how this program was delivered.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mona Fortier
evidence.content: We're hoping that tenants and landlords will be working together so we can support businesses during this very difficult crisis.

evidence.speaker: Ms. Raquel Dancho
evidence.content: Moving on, there are two issues regarding the 50% commercial rent assistance subsidy, where landlords pay 25%, the government pays 50%, and the tenant is responsible for 25%.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mona Fortier
evidence.content: As you know, we've been working with the provinces and territories to provide this forgivable loan to commercial property owners, who in turn lower the rent of their tenants by 75%.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mona Fortier
evidence.content: We will continue to monitor how this program is delivered, as we announced it last week.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mona Fortier
evidence.content: As you know, we've been working with the provinces and territories to provide this forgivable loan to commercial property owners, who in turn lower the rent of their tenants by 75%.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Mona Fortier
evidence.content: We will continue to monitor how this program is delivered, as we announced it last week.

specific_query_list.query: Who would be eligible to receive the art funding?
tokenized_answer: On April 17, the Minister of Canadian Heritage announced funding of $500 million to assist Canada's arts, sports and cultural sectors.
Hon. Steven Guilbeault (Minister of Canadian Heritage) suggested that the department would be releasing the details of that announcement, and how the money was going to be spent in the coming days.

evidence.speaker: Hon. Steven Guilbeault (Minister of Canadian Heritage)
evidence.content: Madam Chair, we will be releasing the details of that announcement, and how the money is going to be spent, in the coming days.

specific_query_list.query: What did the meeting discuss about the various supports for the agricultural sector?
tokenized_answer: It was suggested that farmers and relative products were largely influenced by Covid-19.
Hon. Marie-Claude Bibeau introduced that the government had already confirmed various supports for the agricultural sector.
This week, the government focused on beef and pork producers and processors, as well as sectors with product surpluses that could be redirected to food banks.
At the same time, industry and suppliers had enthusiastically answered the call to equip Canada with products and goods during the crisis.

evidence.content: Support for poultry and egg farmers is in the form of investment programs, which aligns well with the recovery.

evidence.content: At this time, we are focusing on emergency programs to help farmers hardest hit by the COVID-19 pandemic.
